item.title: My last intersection with Jesse Jackson
item.description: The civil rights icon was an agent for chaos and change.

item.title: The Colbert-CBS spat is about overregulation

item.title: Mamdani’s ‘painful’ tax admission
item.description: The next step is understanding that his city has a spending problem, not a revenue problem.

item.description: The climate challenge is more nuanced and manageable than the agency once assumed.

item.description: Olympians bite their medals to test their purity. It used to be the same with currency.

item.description: Trump believes his losing at anything is impossible. Thus, Biden’s win must be fraudulent.

item.title: Rubio and Ocasio-Cortez just made cases to Europe. Only one is right.
item.description: In Munich, the secretary of state and AOC were far apart on the meaning of “order.”

item.title: It took one year for Black MAGA to crater
item.description: The African Americans who voted for Trump are no longer feeling the “love.” Here’s why.

item.title: Move over, athletes. The Olympics have a new star.
item.description: What happens when technology starts to surpass even the greatest athletes on the planet?

item.title: Forget the best president. Who was the most underrated?
item.description: This week, we celebrated Presidents Day, which makes it a fitting time to recognize one of America’s most underrated presidents. Herbert Hoover presided over the onset of the Great Depression and is widely viewed as the inferior predecessor to Franklin D. Roosevelt. But, as host Megan McArdle explains, that judgment is unfair to Hoover. It also reflects a larger problem: the assumption that a president can singlehandedly fix or wreck the economy.

item.title: The lesson of Biden’s failed electric-vehicle push
item.description: The Biden administration used carrots and sticks to steer consumers to electric vehicles. It didn’t work.

item.title: Maintaining America’s edge in the South China Sea
item.description: U.S. missiles in the Philippines help secure the American economy on the cheap.

item.description: Pharmacists, myopia, trust in higher education and Bill Belichick, in readers’ eyes.

item.description: Ratepayers are right to be frustrated about D.C. Water’s performance.

item.description: Three images document Jackson’s journey and his role in expanding the Constitution’s promise of freedom and opportunity.

item.title: Jesse Jackson won in the end
item.description: Like his mentors before him, Jackson has passed the torch. But you can still hear that stirring voice, can’t you?

item.title: A ‘revolution’ is coming for college accreditation
item.description: Federal officials should stop approving accrediting agencies that promote discrimination.
